key_risks: Supply chain vulnerabilities due to semiconductor shortages and geopolitical tensions
Dependence on key markets like automotive and telecommunications
Geopolitical risks including trade wars, tariffs, and regulatory changes
Environmental and ethical concerns related to electronic waste and labor practices
Legal and financial issues including regulatory compliance and labor disputes
controversies: $18 million settlement for violating the False Claims Act
Ongoing labor disputes with the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers
social_issues: Labor practices in the supply chain
Potential operational disruptions from labor disputes
governance_issues: Legal liabilities from non-compliant product sales

sources.title: Electronics Recycling: A Complete Guide to Responsible E-Waste Disposal
sources.snippet: Electronic waste is a growing problem. The world's e-waste generation is far outstripping the effort to recycle e-waste. According to the United Nation's Global E-waste Monitor 2024, the world generated 62 million metric tons of e-waste in 2022. That would fill, "roughly enough trucks to form a bumper-to-bumper line encircling the equator."
